baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT effect of cisterns treatment on requests for private goods from politicians (clientelist behavior), in semi-arid Brazilian municipalities. Household-level RCT with municipality FE and year FE, stacked 2012-2013.
baseline_groups.notes: Two baseline specs from Table 3: Col 3 (joint treatment + rainfall, no interaction) and Col 4 (adds treatment x rainfall interaction). Both produce nearly identical coefficients on the treatment variable (~-0.030). The focal coefficient is on 'treatment' (cistern receipt), not on rainfall. Treatment reduces private goods requests by ~3pp.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT effect of cistern treatment exposure (share of treated in voting section) on votes for incumbent mayor, in municipalities where incumbent ran for re-election. Section-level analysis with voting location FE.
baseline_groups.notes: Single baseline from Table 4 Col 1. Effect of share of cistern-treated on incumbent votes is -0.101, marginally significant (p=0.083). Location FE absorbed. Small effective sample (866 section-observations, ~21 municipalities).

global_notes: No changes to baseline group assignments relative to the surface. The surface correctly identified two baseline groups: G1 (individual-level clientelist behavior, Table 3) and G2 (section-level electoral outcomes, Table 4). The runner produced cross-product combinations of spec_id variations with year subsamples and engagement controls, resulting in duplicate spec_ids within G1 (45 rows vs 21 planned core specs). This is not invalid but reflects a larger-than-planned specification set. All 51 rows are valid and core.
